content.html:
Activity

The number of people who watched a TV episode is a function of that show’s episode number. Here are three graphs of three functions—\(A\), \(B\), and \(C\)—representing three different TV shows.

Show A

Show B

Show C



  1. Match each description with a graph that could represent the situation described. One of the descriptions has no corresponding graph.

    1. This show has a good core audience. It had a guest star in the fifth episode that brought in some new viewers, but most of them stopped watching after that.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

graph of function \(C\)



    1. This show is one of the most popular shows, and its audience keeps increasing.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

no match



    1. This show has a small audience, but it’s improving, so more people are noticing.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

graph of function \(A\)



    1. This show started out huge. Even though it feels like it crashed, it still has more viewers than another show.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

graph of function \(B\)



  1. Which is greatest, \(A(7)\), \(B(7)\), or \(C(7)\)? Explain what the answer tells us about the shows.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(B(7)\). 3.6 million people watched the 7th episode of Show B.




    1. Sketch a graph of the viewership of the fourth TV show that did not have a matching graph.

Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course. Then select the Solution button to check your work:

Compare your answer:


Video: Comparing Functions Represented in Separate Graphs

Watch the following video to learn more about how to compare functions that are represented in separate graphs.
